summary: This document is a New York Statutory Short Form Power of Attorney, granting authority to an agent to manage the principal's financial affairs. It outlines the responsibilities of the agent, the powers granted, and the conditions under which the Power of Attorney remains effective. The document emphasizes the importance of the agent's fiduciary duties and the principal's rights.

persons.name: Jeff Leybstein
persons.context: Jeff Leybstein is designated as an agent in the Power of Attorney document, authorized to act on behalf of the principal.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Darren Indyke is also designated as an agent in the Power of Attorney document, with similar authority to act on behalf of the principal.

connections.description: Both Jeff Leybstein and Darren Indyke are appointed as agents in the Power of Attorney, indicating they may act together or separately as specified.

keyFacts: The Power of Attorney grants the agent authority to manage financial transactions on behalf of the principal.
The document remains effective even if the principal becomes disabled or incompetent.
The principal retains the right to revoke the Power of Attorney at any time as long as they are of sound mind.
The agent has specific legal responsibilities, including acting in the principal's best interest and maintaining separate records.
The document includes provisions for the designation of successor agents and monitors.
